     2â†’
     3â†’This file provides guidance to Claude Code (claude.ai/code) when working with code in this repository.
     4â†’
     5â†’## Commands
     6â†’
     7â†’```bash
     8â†’npm run build        # Compile TypeScript â†’ dist/ (required before running tests)
     9â†’npm run dev          # Watch mode build
    10â†’npm run typecheck    # Type-check without emitting
    11â†’npm test             # Run tests (requires a prior build)
    12â†’```
    13â†’
    14â†’To run tests after code changes: `npm run build && npm test`.
    15â†’
    16â†’Test files live alongside source with `.test.ts` suffixes (e.g. `src/commands/can-exit.test.ts`). Node's built-in test runner (`node --test`) executes them from `dist/testing/index.js`.
    17â†’
    18â†’The `kata` shell script at the repo root is the CLI entry point. It runs `dist/index.js` via Node when built, or falls back to Bun running `src/index.ts` directly for no-build development.
    19â†’
    20â†’## Architecture
    21â†’
    22â†’**kata-wm** is a TypeScript CLI published as an npm package (`kata-wm`). It wraps Claude Code projects with structured session modes, phase task enforcement, and stop hooks.
    23â†’
    24â†’### Source layout (`src/`)
    25â†’
    26â†’| Directory | Purpose |
    27â†’|-----------|---------|
    28â†’| `index.ts` | CLI dispatcher â€” maps `kata <command>` to handler functions; also re-exports the programmatic API |
    29â†’| `commands/` | One file per CLI command (`enter.ts`, `exit.ts`, `hook.ts`, `setup.ts`, etc.) |
    30â†’| `commands/enter/` | Sub-modules for the `enter` command: `task-factory.ts` (native task creation), `guidance.ts`, `template.ts`, `spec.ts` |
    31â†’| `session/lookup.ts` | Project root discovery, session ID resolution, template path resolution |
    32â†’| `state/` | Zod schema (`schema.ts`), reader/writer for `SessionState` JSON |
    33â†’| `config/` | `wm-config.ts` loads `.claude/workflows/wm.yaml`; `cache.ts` loads and merges `modes.yaml` |
    34â†’| `validation/` | Phase/template validation |
    35â†’| `yaml/` | YAML frontmatter parser for template files |
    36â†’| `utils/` | Workflow ID generation, session cleanup, timestamps |
    37â†’| `testing/` | Test utilities exported as `kata-wm/testing` â€” mock sessions, hook runners, assertions, pre-built scenarios |
    38â†’
    39â†’### Build outputs
    40â†’
    41â†’tsup produces ESM-only output with two entry points:
    42â†’- `dist/index.js` â€” main CLI and programmatic API
    43â†’- `dist/testing/index.js` â€” test utilities (also used by `node --test` as the test runner)
    44â†’
    45â†’### Runtime data layout
    46â†’
    47â†’| Path | Contents |
    48â†’|------|---------|
    49â†’| `.claude/sessions/{sessionId}/state.json` | Per-session `SessionState` (mode, phase, workflow ID, history) |
    50â†’| `~/.claude/tasks/{sessionId}/` | Native task files read by `can-exit` and `hook stop-conditions` |
    51â†’| `.claude/workflows/wm.yaml` | Project config (`WmConfig`) |
    52â†’| `.claude/workflows/modes.yaml` | Project-level mode overrides (merged over `modes.yaml` at package root) |
    53â†’| `.claude/workflows/templates/` | Mode templates â€” `onboard.md` seeded by `kata setup`; full set seeded by `kata batteries` |
    54â†’| `planning/spec-templates/` | Spec document stubs â€” feature, bug, epic (copied from `batteries/spec-templates/` during `kata batteries`) |
    55â†’
    56â†’### Hook architecture
    57â†’
    58â†’Hooks are registered in `.claude/settings.json` and call `kata hook <name>`. Each hook reads Claude Code's stdin JSON, extracts `session_id`, and outputs a JSON decision. The session ID from hook stdin **must** be forwarded as `--session=ID` to any subcommand â€” there is no automatic session detection at runtime.
    59â†’
    60â†’| Hook event | Command | Role |
    61â†’|------------|---------|------|
    62â†’| `SessionStart` | `kata hook session-start` | Init session registry, inject mode context |
    63â†’| `UserPromptSubmit` | `kata hook user-prompt` | Detect mode intent, suggest entering a mode |
    64â†’| `Stop` | `kata hook stop-conditions` | Block exit while native tasks are incomplete |
    65â†’| `PreToolUse` (optional) | `kata hook mode-gate` / `task-deps` / `task-evidence` | Strict-mode enforcement |
    66â†’
    67â†’### Mode and template system
    68â†’
    69â†’Built-in modes are defined in `modes.yaml` (package root). Each mode references a template filename with YAML frontmatter defining phases, task titles, and dependency chains.
    70â†’
    71â†’**Template sources:**
    72â†’- `templates/` â€” system templates only: `onboard.md` and `SESSION-TEMPLATE.template.md`
    73â†’- `batteries/templates/` â€” canonical mode templates (implementation, planning, task, bugfix, etc.)
    74â†’
    75â†’After setup, the project owns copies under `.claude/workflows/templates/`. The package files are seeds only, not used at runtime. To update project templates with newer versions, run `kata batteries --update`.
    76â†’
    77â†’Project modes in `.claude/workflows/modes.yaml` are merged over the built-in set with project definitions taking precedence.
    78â†’
    79â†’### Key dependencies
    80â†’
    81â†’- **zod** â€” schema validation for `SessionState`, `ModeConfig`, and config files
    82â†’- **js-yaml** â€” YAML parsing for `modes.yaml`, `wm.yaml`, and template frontmatter
    83â†’
    84â†’## Data-driven design principles
    85â†’
    86â†’**No hardcoded mode names in logic.** Mode behavior is driven by fields in `modes.yaml`:
    87â†’- `issue_handling: "required" | "none"` â€” whether mode entry requires a GitHub issue
    88â†’- `stop_conditions: string[]` â€” which exit checks to run (`tasks_complete`, `committed`, `pushed`, `verification`, `tests_pass`, `feature_tests_added`). Empty array = can always exit.
    89â†’
    90â†’When adding new per-mode behavior, add a field to `modes.yaml` + `ModeConfigSchema`, never hardcode mode names in TypeScript.
    91â†’
    92â†’## Eval harness (`eval/`)
    93â†’
    94â†’Agentic eval suite using `@anthropic-ai/claude-agent-sdk`. The harness drives inner Claude agents through kata scenarios with real tool execution.
    95â†’
    96â†’### Key design decisions
    97â†’
    98â†’- **`settingSources: ['project']`** loads `.claude/settings.json` â€” hooks fire naturally in the SDK, no manual context injection needed. Never use `appendSystemPrompt` for hook context.
    99â†’- **`permissionMode: 'bypassPermissions'`** â€” full agent autonomy, no tool approval prompts.
   100â†’- **AskUserQuestion pause/resume** â€” a PreToolUse hook intercepts AskUserQuestion, stops the session (`continue: false`), outputs question + session_id. Resume with `--resume=<session_id> --answer="<choice>"`.
   101â†’- **Fixture per scenario** â€” `EvalScenario.fixture` field selects which `eval-fixtures/` dir to copy. Fresh projects get `git init` automatically.
   102â†’- **`CLAUDE_PROJECT_DIR` stripped** from inner agent env so it doesn't escape to the outer project.
   103â†’
   104â†’### Running evals
   105â†’
   106â†’```bash
   107â†’npx tsx eval/run.ts --scenario=onboard --verbose       # Single scenario
   108â†’npx tsx eval/run.ts --list                              # List scenarios
   109â†’npx tsx eval/run.ts --scenario=onboard --project=<dir> --resume=<sid> --answer="Quick"  # Resume paused
   110â†’```
   111â†’
   112â†’### Eval mode
   113â†’
   114â†’`eval` is a project-level mode override (`.claude/workflows/modes.yaml`), not in the batteries templates. Enter with `kata enter eval` â€” creates per-scenario tasks with dependency chains.
   115â†’
   116â†’### Fixtures
   117â†’
   118â†’| Fixture | Path | Description |
   119â†’|---------|------|-------------|
   120â†’| `tanstack-start` | `eval-fixtures/tanstack-start/` | Fresh TanStack Start app, no kata config |
   121â†’| `web-app` | `eval-fixtures/web-app/` | Pre-configured with kata hooks, wm.yaml, templates |
   122â†’
   123â†’## Project root resolution
   124â†’
   125â†’`findClaudeProjectDir()` walks up from cwd looking for `.claude/sessions/` or `.claude/workflows/`. It **stops at `.git` boundaries** to prevent escaping into a parent project (e.g., eval projects nested under this repo). If cwd has `.git` but no `.claude/`, it's a fresh project â€” the walk stops there.
   126â†’"}]},"uuid":"b4fae00a-ca1d-4b3a-a8d1-3cb7ad761cfb","timestamp":"2026-02-21T14:59:43.413Z","sourceToolAssistantUUID":"5662bcda-7aea-4835-a4ec-e3498581ece7"}

## TanStack Start App Navigation and Data Loading Patterns

Based on my thorough exploration of the TanStack Start app at `/data/projects/kata-wm/eval-projects/tanstack-start/`, here's what I found:

### PROJECT OVERVIEW

**TanStack Start** is a full-stack React framework using TanStack Router with file-based routing, optimized for server functions, streaming, and type-safe data loading. This is a starter template demonstrating core capabilities.

### FILE STRUCTURE

```
src/
â”œâ”€â”€ router.tsx              # Router initialization and configuration
â”œâ”€â”€ routes/
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ __root.tsx         # Root route layout component
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ index.tsx          # Home page route (/)
â””â”€â”€ styles.css             # Global styles
```

### NAVIGATION PATTERNS

**1. File-Based Routing System:**
- TanStack Router uses file-based routing where files in `src/routes/` automatically become routes
- Route files must export a `Route` constant created with `createFileRoute()` or `createRootRoute()`

**2. Route Definition Pattern:**

From `/data/projects/kata-wm/eval-projects/tanstack-start/src/routes/index.tsx`:
```typescript
import { createFileRoute } from '@tanstack/react-router'

export const Route = createFileRoute('/')({ component: App })

function App() {
  // Component content
}
```

From `/data/projects/kata-wm/eval-projects/tanstack-start/src/routes/__root.tsx`:
```typescript
import { HeadContent, Scripts, createRootRoute } from '@tanstack/react-router'

export const Route = createRootRoute({
  head: () => ({
    meta: [...],
    links: [...]
  }),
  shellComponent: RootDocument,
})
```

**3. Root Route (`__root.tsx`):**
- Special file that defines the app shell/layout
- Wraps all other routes
- Exports `shellComponent: RootDocument` which renders the HTML structure
- Includes `<HeadContent />` for meta tags and `<Scripts />` for client hydration
- Can define global head configuration (metadata, stylesheets, viewport)

**4. Regular Routes (file-based):**
- Each route file exports a `Route` object with `createFileRoute(path)`
- The path corresponds to the file structure (e.g., `index.tsx` = `/`)
- Returns a function that accepts configuration object with `component` property

### ROUTER CONFIGURATION

From `/data/projects/kata-wm/eval-projects/tanstack-start/src/router.tsx`:
```typescript
import { createRouter as createTanStackRouter } from '@tanstack/react-router'
import { routeTree } from './routeTree.gen'

export function getRouter() {
  const router = createTanStackRouter({
    routeTree,
    scrollRestoration: true,      // Restores scroll position on navigation
    defaultPreload: 'intent',     // Preloads routes on hover intent
    defaultPreloadStaleTime: 0,   // Always preload, don't cache
  })
  return router
}
```

**Key Configuration:**
- `routeTree`: Auto-generated from file-based routes (imported from `./routeTree.gen` - generated by TanStack router plugin)
- `scrollRestoration: true`: Maintains scroll position in history
- `defaultPreload: 'intent'`: Preloads route data when user hovers over links
- `defaultPreloadStaleTime: 0`: Fresh preloads every time

### DATA LOADING PATTERNS

**Current Implementation Status:** The starter app contains NO data loading patterns yet.

Based on the app features described and TanStack Router capabilities, here's what IS configured to support:

1. **Server Functions** - Referenced in feature list, enables type-safe serverâ†’client calls
2. **Streaming** - Full streaming support mentioned, allows progressive data loading
3. **SSR (Server-Side Rendering)** - Configured in root route with `<Scripts />` for hydration
4. **Type-Safe Data** - End-to-end TypeScript safety (tsconfig.json has `strict: true`)

### DEPENDENCIES

From `/data/projects/kata-wm/eval-projects/tanstack-start/package.json`:
```json
{
  "@tanstack/react-router": "^1.132.0",         // Core routing
  "@tanstack/react-start": "^1.132.0",          // Full-stack framework
  "@tanstack/react-router-devtools": "^1.132.0", // Debug panel
  "@tanstack/react-router-ssr-query": "^1.131.7", // SSR + query support
  "@tanstack/react-devtools": "^0.7.0",         // Dev tools
  "@tanstack/router-plugin": "^1.132.0",        // Vite plugin for route generation
  "react": "^19.2.0",
  "react-dom": "^19.2.0"
}
```

### BUILD CONFIGURATION

From `/data/projects/kata-wm/eval-projects/tanstack-start/vite.config.ts`:
```typescript
import { tanstackStart } from '@tanstack/react-start/plugin/vite'
import { defineConfig } from 'vite'

const config = defineConfig({
  plugins: [
    devtools(),
    tsconfigPaths({ projects: ['./tsconfig.json'] }),
    tailwindcss(),
    tanstackStart(),    // Auto-generates routeTree.gen, enables SSR
    viteReact(),
  ],
})
```

The `tanstackStart()` plugin:
- Auto-generates `routeTree.gen` from file-based routes
- Enables SSR support
- Handles route code splitting

### DEVELOPMENT COMMANDS

From `/data/projects/kata-wm/eval-projects/tanstack-start/CLAUDE.md`:
```bash
npm install      # Install dependencies
npm run dev      # Start dev server (Vite on port 3000)
npm run build    # Production build
```

### MISSING PATTERNS (Not Yet Implemented)

The current starter does NOT include:
- Route parameters (`$id.tsx` files)
- Search parameters (`useSearch()`)
- Route loaders or `beforeLoad` hooks
- `useParams()` for accessing route params
- `useNavigate()` for programmatic navigation
- `<Link>` components (only using plain `<a>` tags)
- `createServerFn()` for server functions
- `useSuspenseQuery()` or data loading patterns
- Middleware or auth route guards

### DEVTOOLS

- TanStack Router Devtools Panel embedded in app
- Shows route state, navigation history, and preload status
- Positioned bottom-right in development

### TYPE SAFETY

From `/data/projects/kata-wm/eval-projects/tanstack-start/tsconfig.json`:
```typescript
{
  "compilerOptions": {
    "target": "ES2022",
    "jsx": "react-jsx",
    "moduleResolution": "bundler",
    "strict": true,                    // Full type checking
    "noUnusedLocals": true,
    "noUnusedParameters": true,
    "noFallthroughCasesInSwitch": true
  }
}
```

All files are checked with strict TypeScript. Router module augmentation ensures type-safe router access:
```typescript
declare module '@tanstack/react-router' {
  interface Register {
    router: ReturnType<typeof getRouter>
  }
}
```

### ABSOLUTE FILE PATHS REFERENCED

- `/data/projects/kata-wm/eval-projects/tanstack-start/src/router.tsx`
- `/data/projects/kata-wm/eval-projects/tanstack-start/src/routes/__root.tsx`
- `/data/projects/kata-wm/eval-projects/tanstack-start/src/routes/index.tsx`
- `/data/projects/kata-wm/eval-projects/tanstack-start/vite.config.ts`
- `/data/projects/kata-wm/eval-projects/tanstack-start/package.json`
- `/data/projects/kata-wm/eval-projects/tanstack-start/tsconfig.json`

## TanStack Start App Navigation and Data Loading Patterns

Based on my thorough exploration of the TanStack Start app at `/data/projects/kata-wm/eval-projects/tanstack-start/`, here's what I found:

### PROJECT OVERVIEW

**TanStack Start** is a full-stack React framework using TanStack Router with file-based routing, optimized for server functions, streaming, and type-safe data loading. This is a starter template demonstrating core capabilities.

### FILE STRUCTURE

```
src/
â”œâ”€â”€ router.tsx              # Router initialization and configuration
â”œâ”€â”€ routes/
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ __root.tsx         # Root route layout component
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ index.tsx          # Home page route (/)
â””â”€â”€ styles.css             # Global styles
```

### NAVIGATION PATTERNS

**1. File-Based Routing System:**
- TanStack Router uses file-based routing where files in `src/routes/` automatically become routes
- Route files must export a `Route` constant created with `createFileRoute()` or `createRootRoute()`

**2. Route Definition Pattern:**

From `/data/projects/kata-wm/eval-projects/tanstack-start/src/routes/index.tsx`:
```typescript
import { createFileRoute } from '@tanstack/react-router'

export const Route = createFileRoute('/')({ component: App })

function App() {
  // Component content
}
```

From `/data/projects/kata-wm/eval-projects/tanstack-start/src/routes/__root.tsx`:
```typescript
import { HeadContent, Scripts, createRootRoute } from '@tanstack/react-router'

export const Route = createRootRoute({
  head: () => ({
    meta: [...],
    links: [...]
  }),
  shellComponent: RootDocument,
})
```

**3. Root Route (`__root.tsx`):**
- Special file that defines the app shell/layout
- Wraps all other routes
- Exports `shellComponent: RootDocument` which renders the HTML structure
- Includes `<HeadContent />` for meta tags and `<Scripts />` for client hydration
- Can define global head configuration (metadata, stylesheets, viewport)

**4. Regular Routes (file-based):**
- Each route file exports a `Route` object with `createFileRoute(path)`
- The path corresponds to the file structure (e.g., `index.tsx` = `/`)
- Returns a function that accepts configuration object with `component` property

### ROUTER CONFIGURATION

From `/data/projects/kata-wm/eval-projects/tanstack-start/src/router.tsx`:
```typescript
import { createRouter as createTanStackRouter } from '@tanstack/react-router'
import { routeTree } from './routeTree.gen'

export function getRouter() {
  const router = createTanStackRouter({
    routeTree,
    scrollRestoration: true,      // Restores scroll position on navigation
    defaultPreload: 'intent',     // Preloads routes on hover intent
    defaultPreloadStaleTime: 0,   // Always preload, don't cache
  })
  return router
}
```

**Key Configuration:**
- `routeTree`: Auto-generated from file-based routes (imported from `./routeTree.gen` - generated by TanStack router plugin)
- `scrollRestoration: true`: Maintains scroll position in history
- `defaultPreload: 'intent'`: Preloads route data when user hovers over links
- `defaultPreloadStaleTime: 0`: Fresh preloads every time

### DATA LOADING PATTERNS

**Current Implementation Status:** The starter app contains NO data loading patterns yet.

Based on the app features described and TanStack Router capabilities, here's what IS configured to support:

1. **Server Functions** - Referenced in feature list, enables type-safe serverâ†’client calls
2. **Streaming** - Full streaming support mentioned, allows progressive data loading
3. **SSR (Server-Side Rendering)** - Configured in root route with `<Scripts />` for hydration
4. **Type-Safe Data** - End-to-end TypeScript safety (tsconfig.json has `strict: true`)

From `/data/projects/kata-wm/eval-projects/tanstack-start/package.json`:

  "@tanstack/router-plugin": "^1.132.0",        // Vite plugin for route generation

Based on the search results, here's what I found about TanStack Start file-based routing:

## Overview

TanStack Start is built on top of TanStack Router, so all of the features of TanStack Router are available to you. This means that TanStack Start leverages the same file-based routing system that TanStack Router provides.

## How File-Based Routing Works

File-based routing is TanStack Router's system for automatically generating route configurations from filesystem structure. More specifically, file-based routing eliminates manual route configuration by scanning a routes directory and generating a routeTree.gen.ts file that contains all route definitions and TypeScript types.

The system operates at build-time through either the tsr CLI or Vite plugin, watching for file changes and regenerating the route tree as needed.

## Key Features

- The file-based approach is the recommended option for most projects.
- File-based routing requires that you follow a few simple file naming conventions to ensure that your routes are generated correctly.
- The generator produces TypeScript interfaces that enable end-to-end type safety across the routing system.

For more detailed guidance, you can refer to the official TanStack documentation, including resources on file naming conventions, routing concepts, and testing patterns for file-based routing applications.

I found comprehensive information about TanStack Router's data loading features. Here's what the search results reveal:

## Key Functions

The `createFileRoute` function is a factory that can be used to create a file-based route instance, and it accepts a single argument of type string that represents the path of the file that the route will be generated from.

To create a root route, call the `createRootRoute()` function and export it as the Route variable in your route file. For root routes with context, use `createRootRouteWithContext<MyRouterContext>()`.

## Data Loading with Loaders

Routes can use the `loader` option to fetch data, and loaders can also use `loaderDeps` to specify dependencies that trigger reloading when they change.

The execution order is key to understanding data flow in TanStack Router: beforeLoad functions run sequentially from outermost to innermost route, and loader functions run in parallel, but only after ALL beforeLoad functions complete.

## Advanced Features

To defer slow or non-critical data, you can return an unawaited/unresolved promise in your loader response, allowing the next route to begin rendering while deferred promises continue to resolve.

TanStack Router supports caching with a `staleTime` option, and to disable stale-while-revalidate caching for a route, you can set the staleTime option to Infinity.

Context can be set up when starting Router at your application's root using `createRootRouteWithContext`, and different locations in the route tree can add new things to context, which will be visible from there downward in the tree.

content.content:
# TanStack Router Data Loading: Key Concepts

## Execution Order

The critical sequence is:
1. **beforeLoad functions** execute sequentially from outer to inner routes
2. **loader functions** run in parallel, but *only after all beforeLoad functions complete*

This means parent route data reaches child routes, all loaders can access beforeLoad data, yet loaders cannot share data with each other.

## beforeLoad Function

- Receives `{ params, search, context }`
- The `context` parameter contains merged results from parent routes' beforeLoad functions
- Each beforeLoad's return value merges into this context
- Runs sequentially, so slow beforeLoad functions block downstream operations
- Best for authentication, authorization, and shared nested route data

## loader Function

- Receives `{ params, context }`
- To access `search` parameters, you must set `loaderDeps` explicitly
- Has access to the complete merged beforeLoad context
- Each loader's return is independent and isolated from other route loaders
- Runs in parallel, so slow loaders only impact their specific route
- Ideal for route-specific data and heavy fetch operations

## Accessing Data in Components

Use `Route.useRouteContext()` for merged beforeLoad data (including parent data) and `Route.useLoaderData()` for that route's loader data.

## Performance Note

"A slow parent route `beforeLoad` delays ALL child routes" versus loader performance issues affecting only individual routes, making loaders preferable for heavy operations.

content.content:
# TanStack Router File Naming Conventions and Route Tree Generation

## Core File Naming Patterns

TanStack Router uses specific filename conventions to automatically generate route configurations. Here are the primary patterns:

**Root and Index Routes:**
- `__root.tsx` - The application root route (required)
- `index.tsx` - Index route for a path segment (e.g., `/posts/index.tsx` â†’ `/posts`)

**Dynamic Parameters:**
- `$id.tsx` - Creates a dynamic parameter segment (e.g., `/posts/$id.tsx` â†’ `/posts/:id`)
- `$` prefix denotes path parameters that are type-safe and validated

**Layout Routes (Pathless):**
- `_layoutName/` - Directory prefixed with underscore creates a layout without adding to URL path
- Example: `_auth/login.tsx` â†’ `/login` (inherits `_auth` layout)

**Route Groups:**
- `(groupName)/` - Parenthetical directory names organize routes without affecting URLs
- Example: `(admin)/users.tsx` â†’ `/users` (group removed from path)

**Explicit Route Files:**
- `*.route.tsx` - Explicitly marks a file as a route definition
- `*.lazy.tsx` - Designates lazy-loaded route components

**Ignored Files:**
- `-filename.tsx` - Files with this prefix are excluded from routing (configurable via `routeFileIgnorePrefix`)

## Route Tree Generation Process

The generator transforms your filesystem structure into type-safe routing code through several stages:

**Pipeline Overview:**
1. Scan the routes directory for files matching naming conventions
2. Parse file structure to determine route hierarchy
3. Generate `routeTree.gen.ts` containing all route definitions
4. Produce TypeScript interfaces for type safety

**Key Generation Features:**

The system creates "FileRoutesByPath" interfaces that map URL paths to route metadata, enabling autocomplete in navigation calls. Generated types include route parameters, search schemas, and loader data types inferred from your route definitions.

**Cache Strategy:**

The generator maintains dual cachesâ€”a primary cache and shadow cacheâ€”to ensure atomic updates. File modification times are compared against cached entries; only changed files are regenerated. This optimization significantly speeds up builds with large route trees.

**Module Augmentation:**

When `verboseFileRoutes: false`, the generator creates module declarations that allow route files to reference their paths implicitly, reducing boilerplate in individual route definitions.

## File Type Classification

The system assigns each file a classification determining its role:

- `__root` - Application root
- `index` - Index route for segment
- `route` - Explicit route configuration
- `lazy` - Lazy-loaded component
- `layout` - Pathless layout route
- `component` - Route component piece
- `errorComponent` - Error boundary
- `pendingComponent` - Loading state
- `loader` - Data loader piece

This classification drives the code generation pipeline and determines how files contribute to the final route tree structure.

- `$id.tsx` - Creates a dynamic parameter segment (e.g., `/posts/$id.tsx` â†’ `/posts/:id`)
- `$` prefix denotes path parameters that are type-safe and validated

**Layout Routes (Pathless):**
- `_layoutName/` - Directory prefixed with underscore creates a layout without adding to URL path
- Example: `_auth/login.tsx` â†’ `/login` (inherits `_auth` layout)

**Route Groups:**
- `(groupName)/` - Parenthetical directory names organize routes without affecting URLs
- Example: `(admin)/users.tsx` â†’ `/users` (group removed from path)

**Explicit Route Files:**
- `*.route.tsx` - Explicitly marks a file as a route definition
- `*.lazy.tsx` - Designates lazy-loaded route components

**Ignored Files:**
- `-filename.tsx` - Files with this prefix are excluded from routing (configurable via `routeFileIgnorePrefix`)

## Route Tree Generation Process

The generator transforms your filesystem structure into type-safe routing code through several stages:

**Pipeline Overview:**
1. Scan the routes directory for files matching naming conventions
2. Parse file structure to determine route hierarchy
3. Generate `routeTree.gen.ts` containing all route definitions
4. Produce TypeScript interfaces for type safety

**Key Generation Features:**

The system creates "FileRoutesByPath" interfaces that map URL paths to route metadata, enabling autocomplete in navigation calls. Generated types include route parameters, search schemas, and loader data types inferred from your route definitions.

**Cache Strategy:**

The generator maintains dual cachesâ€”a primary cache and shadow cacheâ€”to ensure atomic updates. File modification times are compared against cached entries; only changed files are regenerated. This optimization significantly speeds up builds with large route trees.

**Module Augmentation:**

When `verboseFileRoutes: false`, the generator creates module declarations that allow route files to reference their paths implicitly, reducing boilerplate in individual route definitions.

## File Type Classification

The system assigns each file a classification determining its role:

- `__root` - Application root
- `index` - Index route for segment
- `route` - Explicit route configuration
- `lazy` - Lazy-loaded component
- `layout` - Pathless layout route
- `component` - Route component piece
- `errorComponent` - Error boundary
- `pendingComponent` - Loading state
- `loader` - Data loader piece

This classification drives the code generation pipeline and determines how files contribute to the final route tree structure.

# Research: How Routing Works in This TanStack Start App

## Context

Exploratory research to understand how file-based routing is structured in this TanStack Start starter app, including route definitions, the auto-generated route tree, navigation patterns, and data loading capabilities.

## Questions Explored

1. How is file-based routing structured in this app?
2. How does the route tree get generated?
3. What navigation and data loading patterns are available?
4. What conventions govern route file naming?

## Findings

### Codebase

#### Route File Structure

This is a minimal starter with only two route files:

```
src/
â”œâ”€â”€ router.tsx              # Router factory â€” creates and configures the router instance
â”œâ”€â”€ routes/
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ __root.tsx         # Root layout â€” HTML shell wrapping all routes
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ index.tsx          # Home page â€” maps to /
â””â”€â”€ styles.css
```

#### Root Route (`src/routes/__root.tsx`)

- Uses `createRootRoute()` from `@tanstack/react-router`
- Defines `head()` â€” HTML metadata (charset, viewport, title, stylesheet link)
- Exports `shellComponent: RootDocument` â€” the HTML document wrapper
- `RootDocument` renders `<HeadContent />`, `{children}` (nested routes), `<Scripts />` (hydration), and devtools panels
- Every route in the app renders inside this shell

#### Index Route (`src/routes/index.tsx`)

- Uses `createFileRoute('/')` â€” the file-based route factory
- Pattern: `export const Route = createFileRoute('/')({ component: App })`
- Renders a hero page showcasing TanStack Start features (server functions, SSR, streaming, type safety)
- No data loading, no route params â€” purely static content

#### Router Configuration (`src/router.tsx`)

- Imports auto-generated `routeTree` from `./routeTree.gen`
- Creates router via `createTanStackRouter({ routeTree, ... })`
- Key settings:
  - `scrollRestoration: true` â€” restores scroll position on back/forward
  - `defaultPreload: 'intent'` â€” preloads routes when user hovers/focuses links
  - `defaultPreloadStaleTime: 0` â€” always fresh preloads
- TypeScript module augmentation registers the router type globally for type safety

#### Build Pipeline (`vite.config.ts`)

Plugins in order: `devtools()`, `tsconfigPaths()`, `tailwindcss()`, `tanstackStart()`, `viteReact()`

The `tanstackStart()` Vite plugin from `@tanstack/react-start/plugin/vite`:
- Scans `src/routes/` at build time
- Auto-generates `src/routeTree.gen.ts` with the complete route tree + TypeScript types
- Regenerates on file changes during `npm run dev`
- The `.vscode/settings.json` marks `routeTree.gen.ts` as read-only

#### Dependencies (all at `^1.132.0`)

| Package | Role |
|---------|------|
| `@tanstack/react-router` | Core routing engine |
| `@tanstack/react-start` | Full-stack framework (SSR, server functions) |
| `@tanstack/router-plugin` | Vite plugin for route tree generation |
| `@tanstack/react-router-devtools` | Router debug panel |
| `@tanstack/react-router-ssr-query` | SSR + TanStack Query integration |

#### What's NOT Implemented Yet

- No `<Link>` components (only plain `<a>` tags)
- No `useNavigate()` or programmatic navigation
- No route parameters (`$id.tsx` patterns)
- No `loader` or `beforeLoad` functions
- No `createServerFn()` server functions
- No search params (`useSearch()`)
- No middleware or auth guards

### External (TanStack Router Documentation)

#### File Naming Conventions

| Pattern | Meaning | Example |
|---------|---------|---------|
| `__root.tsx` | App root layout (required) | Wraps all routes |
| `index.tsx` | Index route for segment | `posts/index.tsx` â†’ `/posts` |
| `$param.tsx` | Dynamic parameter | `posts/$id.tsx` â†’ `/posts/:id` |
| `_layoutName/` | Pathless layout (underscore prefix) | `_auth/login.tsx` â†’ `/login` with auth layout |
| `(groupName)/` | Route group (no URL impact) | `(admin)/users.tsx` â†’ `/users` |
| `*.lazy.tsx` | Lazy-loaded component | Code-split route |
| `-filename.tsx` | Ignored file | Excluded from routing |

#### Data Loading Model

**Execution order:**
1. `beforeLoad` runs **sequentially** from outermost â†’ innermost route
2. `loader` runs **in parallel** (only after ALL `beforeLoad` complete)

**`beforeLoad`** â€” receives `{ params, search, context }`:
- Return value merges into context for child routes
- Best for: auth checks, shared data, redirects
- Caution: slow beforeLoad blocks ALL children

**`loader`** â€” receives `{ params, context }`:
- Returns route-specific data
- Access via `Route.useLoaderData()` in component
- Runs in parallel â€” slow loader only affects its own route
- Must use `loaderDeps` to reactively depend on search params

**Context flow:** `Route.useRouteContext()` gives merged beforeLoad data from all ancestors.

#### Route Tree Generation Pipeline

1. Scanner watches `src/routes/` for files matching naming conventions
2. Parser builds route hierarchy from filesystem structure
3. Generator produces `routeTree.gen.ts` with TypeScript interfaces
4. Types enable autocomplete for paths, params, and search schemas
5. Dual-cache system ensures fast incremental rebuilds

## Recommendations

| If You Want To... | Do This |
|-------------------|---------|
| Add a new page | Create `src/routes/about.tsx` with `createFileRoute('/about')` |
| Add dynamic routes | Create `src/routes/posts/$id.tsx` with `createFileRoute('/posts/$id')` |
| Add a shared layout | Create `src/routes/_dashboard/` directory with layout route |
| Load data for a route | Add `loader` option to `createFileRoute()` call |
| Add auth guards | Use `beforeLoad` to check auth and `redirect()` if unauthorized |
| Navigate programmatically | Use `useNavigate()` hook or `<Link to="/path">` component |

## Open Questions

- How does `@tanstack/react-router-ssr-query` integrate with route loaders? (dependency is installed but unused)
- What is the recommended pattern for server functions (`createServerFn`) in route loaders?

## Next Steps

- None required â€” this is a learning exploration
- If building features: start by adding routes with data loading to exercise the full routing system

## Sources

- [File-Based Routing | TanStack Router Docs](https://tanstack.com/router/v1/docs/framework/react/routing/file-based-routing)
- [Routing | TanStack Start Docs](https://tanstack.com/start/latest/docs/framework/react/guide/routing)
- [Data Loading | TanStack Router Docs](https://tanstack.com/router/v1/docs/framework/react/guide/data-loading)
- [File-Based Routing | DeepWiki](https://deepwiki.com/TanStack/router/4.1-file-based-routing)
- [TanStack Router Data Loading | Ben Houston](https://benhouston3d.com/blog/tanstack-router-beforeLoad-loader)
- [createFileRoute API | TanStack Router Docs](https://tanstack.com/router/v1/docs/framework/react/api/router/createFileRouteFunction)

content.text:
## Research Summary: TanStack Start Routing

### How routing works in this app

This is a **minimal TanStack Start starter** with file-based routing powered by `@tanstack/router-plugin`. Here's the complete picture:

**Route files** â†’ `src/routes/`

| File | Route | Role |
|------|-------|------|
| `__root.tsx` | (all routes) | HTML shell â€” `<head>`, `<body>`, devtools |
| `index.tsx` | `/` | Home page with feature showcase |

**How it connects:**
1. The Vite plugin `tanstackStart()` scans `src/routes/` at build time
2. It auto-generates `src/routeTree.gen.ts` â€” the complete route tree with TypeScript types
3. `src/router.tsx` imports that tree and creates the router with scroll restoration + intent-based preloading
4. Module augmentation makes the router type-safe globally

**What's available but not yet used:**
- Dynamic routes (`$id.tsx` â†’ `/posts/:id`)
- Layouts (`_layoutName/` directories)
- Data loading (`loader` + `beforeLoad` on routes)
- Server functions (`createServerFn`)
- `<Link>` components and `useNavigate()`

**Key insight:** `beforeLoad` runs sequentially (parent â†’ child), then all `loader` functions run in **parallel**. This means auth checks go in `beforeLoad`, data fetching goes in `loader`.

The full research doc is committed at `planning/research/2026-02-21-tanstack-start-routing.md`.
